description.en:
Course description. Since the launch of the euro in the late-1990s, the EU's Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) has represented a stark symmetry between the fully integrated "monetary" arm and only partially integrated "economic" arm. The incomplete nature of the EMU was fully exposed by the sovereign debt crisis of 2010, entailing enforced macro-economic, fiscal (but also social) governance frameworks, new financial assistance funds, as well as significant advances in coordinating financial and capital markets. However, the Covid-19 crisis and the EU's responses to it - effectively endowing the European Commission with fiscal and debt-raising powers - have marked a major leap forward in EU economic governance, effectively closing the long-standing asymmetry between monetary and fiscal realms. 

This MA course has two basic objectives. First, to provide an overview of the development of the EU's fiscal policy, monetary policy, and financial and capital market regulation before and after the Sovereign Debt Crisis. Second, to provide a topical perspective on the ongoing changes in EU economic governance in the current polycrisis, as related to COVID-19, climate change and Russia's war in Ukraine. The course will provide a broad overview of these policy developments and explain how they are shaped by national and supranational actors and institutions. The course will be of high relevance to MA students of political science, economics and law.
description.et:
Alates euro kasutuselevõtust 1990. aastate lõpus on ELi majandus- ja rahaliit (EMU) kujutanud endast teravat sümmeetriat täielikult integreeritud "raha" ja ainult osaliselt integreeritud "majanduse" haru vahel. Majandus- ja rahaliidu ebatäielikkust paljastas täielikult 2010. aasta riigivõlakriis, mis tõi kaasa makromajandusliku, fiskaal- (aga ka sotsiaalse) juhtimisraamistiku, uued finantsabi fondid ning märkimisväärsed edusammud finants- ja kapitaliturgude koordineerimisel. Siiski on Covid-19 kriis ja ELi reageeringud sellele - andes Euroopa Komisjonile tõhusad volitused fiskaal- ja võlgade tõstmiseks - tähistanud suurt edasiminekut ELi majanduse juhtimises, kaotades tõhusalt pikaajalise asümmeetria raha- ja eelarvevaldkonna vahel. Sellegipoolest on praegusel hetkel raske ennustada, kas ja mil määral COVID-i järgsed kokkulepped kestavad.

 

Vaadeldes kõige olulisemaid arenguid ELi majanduse juhtimises ja poliitikas alates Maastrichti lepingust (1992) kuni Covid-19 kriisini (2020), näitab see MA kursus, kuidas ELi poliitika on visiooniliste ideede ja jõu tulemus. -ühelt poolt mäng ning teiselt poolt funktsionaalsed vajadused ja globaalsed arengud. Andes põhjaliku pildi sellest, kuidas erinevad ELi majanduspoliitikad on viimase kolme aastakümne jooksul muutunud - ja mida on juhtinud - erinevad riiklikud ja riigiülesed osalejad ja institutsioonid, pakub kursus huvi mitte ainult ELi poliitika ja rahvusvaheliste suhete eriala üliõpilastele vaid ka tulevastele poliitikakujundajatele. Lisaks on kursus kasulik abijuhend kvalitatiivse (politoloogia) metoodika rakendamisel EL-i poliitika ja integratsiooni uurimisel.

objectives.en: This course is designed to provide EU politics and IR students, but also policy makers to-be with expertise on EU economic governance and politics behind it. By specifically focusing on governance of fiscal, economic and social policy in a historical perspective, the course aims at profound understanding of the ever-changing policy agenda and modes of governance of the EU. It shows how the politics, policies and polity of the EU are the result of visionary ideas and power-play on the one hand, and functional necessities and global developments on the other hand. In addition, it provides basic understanding of social science research methods, focusing on those elements that are most relevant for policy practice.
objectives.et: Selle kursuse eesmärk on anda ELi poliitika ja rahvusvaheliste suhete üliõpilastele, aga ka tulevastele poliitikakujundajatele teadmisi ELi majandusjuhtimise ja selle taga oleva poliitika kohta. Konkreetselt keskendudes eelarve-, majandus- ja sotsiaalpoliitika juhtimisele ajaloolises perspektiivis, on kursuse eesmärk saada põhjalik mõistmine pidevalt muutuvatest poliitilistest tegevuskavadest ja ELi valitsemisviisidest. See näitab, kuidas ELi poliitika on ühelt poolt visiooniliste ideede ja võimumängu ning teiselt poolt funktsionaalsete vajaduste ja globaalsete arengute tulemus. Lisaks annab see põhiteadmised sotsiaalteaduste uurimismeetoditest, keskendudes elementidele, mis on poliitikapraktika jaoks kõige olulisemad.

notes.et:
Out of 14 sessions, 12 sessions consist of a lecture followed by a discussion. 2 sessions are fully devoted to student presentations.

All reading materials will be provided in the Moodle.

independent_work.et: In order to be considered for the final assessment, students are expected to attend all but two classes, submit two assignments (memos), participate in a presentation, and submit a final essay (for details see below).

description.et: First, students are expected to write 3 analytical memos of 500 words for any three meetings (apart from the first-, the last-, and the meeting devoted to presentations. The memo must engage with 3 of the assigned readings, to answer the set of questions as prepared by the lecturer. The memos must be submitted 1 day before the respective sessions. The function of the memos is NOT testing of knowledge, but to prepare for the class discussion. The assessment criteria will mainly focus on whether and how the students have answered the set of questions. Each assignment will be assessed on a scale up to 10 points (from 5 points = "sufficient", to 10 points = "excellent"). For the three assignments students will be able to earn 30 points. If the submission deadline is missed, evaluation points will be decreased (2 for first, 1 for every next day; illness is not an excuse

Second, students will have to participate in one group presentation of 15 min, to answer concrete questions (specified before). Presentation will be assessed on a scale up to 30 points (from 15 points = "sufficient", to 30 points = "excellent")

Students will have to write a final essay of 2000-3000 words, on a topic coordinated with the lecturer. The final assignment will be assessed from 20 points = "sufficient", to 40 points = "excellent"). If the submission deadline is missed, evaluation points will be decreased (1 for every day, illness is not an excuse).

grade_preconditions.et:
First, students are expected to write 2 analytical memos of 500 words for any two meetings (apart from the first-, the last-, and the meeting devoted to presentations. The memo must engage with the 2-3 of the assigned readings, to answer the set of questions as prepared by the lecturer. The memos must be submitted 1 day before the respective sessions at 1pm. The function of the memos is NOT testing of knowledge, but to prepare for the class discussion.

Each assignment will be assessed on a scale up to 15 points. For the two assignments students will be able to earn 30 points. If the submission deadline is missed, evaluation points will be decreased (2 for first, 1 for every next day; illness is not an excuse)

Second, students will have to participate in one group presentation of 20 min, to answer concrete questions (specified before) and lead a class discussion.

Presentation will be assessed on a scale up to 30 points. Detailed instructions and assessment criteria will be outlined in guidelines in Moodle.

grade_evaluation.et:
Students will have to write a final essay of 2000 words, on a topic coordinated with the lecturer. The final assignment will be assessed on a scale up to 40 points, detailed instructions and assessment criteria will be outlined in guidelines in Moodle. If the submission deadline is missed, evaluation points will be decreased (1 for every day, illness is not an excuse).

Once the minimum requirements to be considered for the final assessment are met, the components of the final evaluation will weight in the definition of the final grade according to the following distribution of points:
- Two assignments: 30 (differentiated)
- Presentation: 30 (differentiated)
- Final essay / course paper: 40 (differentiated)
Total max: 100 points
Minimum points required for assessment: 51.

Pagiarism is NOT TOLERATED and can lead to failing the course. More details are available at www.plagiarism.org.
